Quantum theory is a highly successful and elegant way of describing the physical world. However, it is not a theory in the ordinary sense of the word, in that it is not based on a set of axioms. This has led to a number of attempts to provide a set of axioms for quantum theory, with the goal of understanding it as a particular case of a more general theory. We provide a set of axioms that, in our view, guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This is a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory, and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to evolutionary biologists because of their extreme reduction in gene content and body plan. Here, we report the results of a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and a less reduced cnidarian, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. We also show that myxozoans are among the most reduced animals in terms of genome size and gene content. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa and the extreme reduction in gene content and body plan that characterizes this group of parasites. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 10 million deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2. Here, we show that the viral accessory protein ORF6 is able to block nuclear import of the STAT1 and STAT2 heterodimer. We found that the protein localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex involved in nuclear import. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of interferon. This mechanism may be used by other viruses to evade IFN signaling. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, but the impact of temperature variability on yield is not well understood. Here, we quantify the impact of temperature variability on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 86% under 4 °C warming, which is a significant increase in instability in global grain trade and international grain prices. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. These findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The cosmic ray exposure ages of presolar silicon carbide grains from the Murchison CM2 meteorite are determined. The grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. This indicates that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all life on Earth. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most limiting factor in the evolution of mammals. We find that the ability to provide food to offspring during pregnancy correlates with increased reproductive output. This effect is most pronounced in species that practice allonursing, where the mother provides food to the offspring after birth. Our results suggest that the ability to reproduce is the most limiting factor in the evolution of placental mammals. This finding has implications for the evolution of the placenta, the evolution of mammals, and the evolution of life on Earth. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebral cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the neurotoxic effects of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA and opens the way for further preclinical and clinical studies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling inflammation, and controlling blood pressure. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control these functions by integrating multiple lines of information. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The communication network is found to be a small-world network, which is a configuration that is both efficient at local and global communication. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for both local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This work provides a better understanding of the communication network and its role in the control of cardiovascular activity. It also provides a model for the design of networks in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges, both for public health and for researchers. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is the gate that opens the channel to allow ions to flow through. We have shown that the activation gate can affect the conformation of the selectivity filter, and that this allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and protozoa that is thought to play a critical role in the health of the animal host. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is less well understood, but they are known to be abundant and diverse in the digestive tracts of herbivores. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tracts of herbivores. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy

The ability to program mechanical behaviors of materials and structures is of great importance for the development of functional devices. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular distributions of material phases, yet they are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of programmable mechanical devices.

The hemoglobin system is a major regulator of the timing of development and aging in vertebrates. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in humans. IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal liver and upregulated in erythroid tissues, where it mediates a developmental reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern. This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and aging. The results also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is a recently discovered form of cell death that is regulated by a variety of cellular processes, including metabolism, redox homeostasis, and signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway is highly mutated in human cancer, conferring resistance to ferroptosis. We also found that this resistance is mediated by activation of mTORC1 and induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Finally, we showed that this resistance can be overcome by targeting mTORC1 and ferroptosis induction simultaneously, and that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI pathway, which is a major pathway for store-operated Ca2+ entry. Our findings suggest that LCCBs may promote vascular remodeling and heart failure through activation of the STIM/ORAI pathway. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism of LCCB action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of these species on private lands where clearcutting continued. The NWFP’s success in halting the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations is encouraging, but the policy failed to halt the decline of these species on federal lands where clearcutting continued. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, since the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens to antibiotics is a major obstacle. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate designed by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and that it is more accessible, exhibits higher solubility, and has higher binding affinity to the ribosome than the best candidate identified by screening. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to identify new antibiotics for a wide range of pathogens. This will help to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens to antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training examples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is able to adapt to different problems automatically. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to train and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The evolution of Lake Malawi, East Africa, is a classic example of the impact of climate change on the landscape and biodiversity of the tropics. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the tropics, which shows that the evolution of the lake was driven by changes in the effective moisture of the climate system. We observe a dramatic shift in the effective moisture regime at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which is consistent with the onset of the last interglacial. The lake was often overfilled during the last interglacial, indicating a climate wetter than today. This study demonstrates the importance of understanding the hydroclimate of the tropics to understand the evolution of the Earth system.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the effects of this practice on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the following night’s sleep. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by electronic devices, given that artificial-light exposure has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Ytterby meteorite, which fell in Sweden in 1911, contains 187Os/188Os of 0.13, similar to the lowest values reported in this study. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania are <<1.0, suggesting that the samples are mixtures of terrestrial and extraterrestrial materials. However, the Os concentration in bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from Belgium is low, indicating no meteoritic contribution. The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate beetle diversification rates and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose using 154 genomes or transcriptomes. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the engineering of other protein molecules.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural ecologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to expectations, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, it is the social-learning process that generates greater variation in plane performance and gives participants access to better-adapted planes. This suggests that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of culture and the emergence of technology.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a protein that is synthesized by astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. APOE is also a major protein of senescent synapses, which are highly vulnerable to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased risk of AD in individuals with the APOE4 allele. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a rationale for the use of APOE-targeted drugs in AD therapy.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 1,200 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has not been well understood. Here, we show that the nucleation of the stable, body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in the brain’s response to the drug, which is consistent with their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation is a potential mechanism underlying the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning models that have been trained on unrelated tasks can predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences in the context of a neuroscience challenge. This result suggests that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. These results provide computational guidance for future neuroscience and language research, and they suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism of higher-level cognition. This may have implications for the study of intelligence and the evolution of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the use of algorithms that are not well-conditioned, and that the instability can be eliminated by using algorithms that are well-conditioned. We also introduce a new algorithm that is both simple and fast, and we prove that it is stable.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of people to take the necessary precautions. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major factor in the spread of the virus. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Here, we discuss the flaws of the experiment and show that it is not only a poor example of psychological research but also a poor example of science in general.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still with us today. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, which is characterized by the presence of a large number of lymphocytes in the skin, has remained a mystery. We have sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of this reactional state, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We find that the two organisms are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This suggests that the two organisms have been evolving together for thousands of years, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases.

The evolution of entanglement is a fundamental question in quantum mechanics. It is also a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. However, the entanglement dynamics is a nonperturbative problem, which is hard to solve exactly. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are not 100% effective, and the pandemic is not yet under control. Therefore, the development of a safe and effective vaccine is of utmost importance. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons. This recoding introduces 283 silent mutations, which are expected to improve the safety and efficacy of the vaccine. The recoded virus is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The recoded virus is also highly attenuated, as shown by its protective efficacy in hamsters. The recoded virus is a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease spread rapidly through Europe, killing millions of people. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodents and fleas being the most likely candidates. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by fleas during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of the disease, as well as for the spread of Y. pestis today.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density, which is the brain’s computational power, has been neglected. Here, we show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target, but current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other member of the HSP90 chaperone family. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may be particularly true in the context of cancers that express less TRAP1 than do their normal tissue counterparts. This may be a significant finding in the context of the current debate over the role of HSP90 inhibitors in cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are dynamically disassembled and reassembled by a family of proteins. These proteins are important regulators of cell shape and motility, and they are also involved in diseases such as cancer metastasis. The proteins of this family are small, and they are thought to bind to actin filaments and to dissociate them from each other. However, how they do so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that the proteins of this family can induce a mechanical torque on filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is a general feature of actin filament disassembly. It is likely to be important in many biological processes, including cell motility and cancer metastasis. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is thought to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study provides evidence that fructose relative to glucose may promote feeding behavior. The results suggest that fructose may be a stronger trigger of hunger and desire for food and a greater risk factor for overeating. The findings also suggest that fructose may activate brain regions involved in attention and reward processing, which may contribute to the development of obesity. These results are consistent with the notion that the metabolic effects of fructose may be mediated by its effects on insulin signaling. Future studies are needed to determine whether the observed effects of fructose on brain and behavior can be modified by dietary context and other factors. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to investigate the settlement history of Madagascar. We find that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed with a few Asian and European contributions. The settlement history of Madagascar is also shown to be sex biased, with a higher contribution of Asian ancestry to males. This study shows that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent waves of migration, which is in contrast to the single-wave hypothesis. Finally, we show that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its genetic structure, which is a result of the recent settlement of Madagascar. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of RNA modifications in coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to have a variety of effects on mRNA stability, translation, and protein function. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on the ribosome and protein synthesis has not been well characterized. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can have a significant impact on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor EF-Tu and can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have a significant impact on protein synthesis. This work also provides a structural basis for the effects of Ψ on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better social and economic well-being, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. Longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is a strong predictor of positive changes in these outcomes over a 4-y period. This feeling may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the extent to which aquatic mammals are constrained by the aquatic environment remains unclear. We use a model of the energetic costs and benefits of body size to show that aquatic mammals are driven to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and it replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C, and this temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C led to higher levels of type I IFN induction at 37 °C than at 33 °C, and this temperature-dependent IFN induction correlated with higher levels of ISG induction at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics. (

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced virulence and biofilm-inducing genes, and is required for the long-term attachment of the bacterium to surfaces. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more rapidly. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of our planet. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water and sediments. The results of this study are of great importance for the future of our planet, as the use of pesticides in agriculture is expected to increase further.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus has spread to many animal species, including deer. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, which is a significant finding because deer are a major cervid in North America. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that are needed to move toward sustainable hydropower. The paper also examines the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the activation of microglia, the resident immune cells of the central nervous system (CNS). Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an immune response, and that this response is unique to the brain’s Aβ environment. We demonstrate that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory molecules in the brain, and that these molecules are necessary for the activation of microglia. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response in AD. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most successful examples of human-animal cooperation. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is, however, still elusive. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for rapid degradation of the capsulated RNA. In Escherichia coli, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in such conditions, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a mechanism for the differential impact of stress on the rates at which capped and uncapped 5′ termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation. The implications of this work for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress are discussed. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be used as a nutritional supplement to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass of different taxa.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with no external control parameter oscillate between two or more distinct states. The most famous example is the sandpile model, where the system is a network of resistors, and the critical state is a state where the system is in a state of self-sustained oscillations. In this paper, we show that the sandpile model has a continuous limit, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. This limit is a continuous model of SOC. We also show that the sandpile model has a continuous limit, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. This limit is a continuous model of SOC.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings also provide insights into the physics of metallization and the mechanism of phonon instability. The findings are expected to inspire new research directions in the field of materials science.

The study of the structure and function of plant immune peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is of particular interest because of the importance of fungal pathogens in agriculture. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a plant immune peptide, NCR044, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptides. We show that this peptide is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and that it binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the male–female interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become a substantial component of the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The mechanism is similar to that of GPIbα, suggesting that the binding reaction is regulated. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The mechanism also suggests that VWF may be a useful therapeutic target.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been shown to influence health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of a lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a resource for the human virome, which is expected to be a rich source of information about the impact of viruses on human health. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results suggest that viruses may play a more significant role in human disease than previously thought.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. Continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth is of particular interest because it is the origin of life. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is inferred to have been high, but the actual temperature is unknown. We present a method for determining the temperature of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can exhibit slow C-type inactivation/recovery, which is state-dependent and can be prevented by an open-state mutation. We propose that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery in K+ channels. It also provides a new mechanism for the BK channel’s slow C-type inactivation/recovery and its role in the control of cardiac excitability. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of death worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the major barriers to treatment is the ability of the parasite to invade the red blood cell, the target of the immune response. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the red cell surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that the parasite primes the red cell surface, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding has major implications for our understanding of malaria invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This may provide a target for new treatments. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, and it is unclear how strain can be used to tune its properties. Here, we show that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond, and we demonstrate that strain can be used to control the phase of diamond. These findings open up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in quantum technologies, energy storage, and optoelectronics.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus transmission and disease outcome, and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat influenza virus infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, whether the brain actually builds such a tree structure remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to build a hierarchy of phrases from the incoming language stream. This parser may be a fundamental component of the brain’s language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt pathway. We believe that this study will help to understand the mechanisms of gene redundancy and will be of interest to the general scientific community.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is blocked by lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra, suggesting that dopamine is involved in the LH circuit. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, suggesting that this circuit is downstream of dopamine. Finally, we show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, suggesting that this circuit is downstream of dopamine. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen is a key trait for plants. However, only a small fraction of the atmospheric N2 is fixed by the few organisms that possess the nitrogenase enzyme complex. The ability to control the establishment of the biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) symbiosis between plants and their rhizobia would allow for the delivery of BNF to plants that do not naturally support this process. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the establishment of the BNF symbiosis in a cereal crop, barley, using a synthetic signaling system. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of synthetic signaling systems in the control of the BNF symbiosis.

The Amazon is the world’s largest tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize community-based patrols, but the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are not. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 1.5 million lives worldwide and continues to spread. The global distribution of COVID-19 vaccines is not equitable, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) are still waiting for access to vaccines. To address this, we engineered a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. We show that this variant is highly manufacturable, binds to ACE2 with high affinity, and elicits antibodies with high neutralizing activity against the variants of concern. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD can be used as a component of a vaccine, which may help to accelerate the global distribution of vaccines. This work provides a potential solution to the global distribution of COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

The role of the ALK receptor in development and cancer is well established. Here, we show that the ALKAL proteins, which are secreted small proteins, are ligands for ALK and that they are involved in neural crest development. We provide evidence that ALKALs are able to activate ALK/LTK receptors in vivo and in vitro. Our results provide insights into the role of ALKALs in cancer and development and open up new avenues for the development of ALKAL-targeted therapies.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is a key event in human history, and its history is poorly understood due to the lack of ancient genomic data. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which is a critical time for the development of human societies. Our results show that Y. pestis was not a local Eurasian pathogen, but rather a cosmopolitan plague, which spread across Eurasia and beyond. This study also reveals that the plague lineage that gave rise to the LNBA plague was not diverse, and that the plague was likely adapted to fleas during this period. These findings provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and the role of fleas in its spread. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of the global food system. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to massive emissions of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition, can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated SOC in the United States. However, these practices did not increase the amount of SOC stored in particulate organic matter, which is the most labile fraction of SOC. These results highlight the importance of managing grasslands to sequester SOC and highlight the need for further research on the fate of SOC in agricultural systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a spillover risk to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from a virus discovery project, we validated the risk assessment and ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We capitalized on the recent wealth of virus discovery data to systematically identify and prioritize targets for investigation. The publicly accessible SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards that plants offer to pollinators is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood, as there are no population-level genome data from this time period. Here we present genome data from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the men’s genomes are mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but the women’s genomes exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we find that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for preventing future zoonotic outbreaks. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) on sera from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings suggest that mNGS is a feasible and revealing approach for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify pathogens that are not detected by current diagnostic methods. The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the molecular mechanisms that govern the replication of the lagging strand are different in humans and yeast. In humans, the lagging strand is replicated by a single DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) that is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. We have developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not very processive and dissociates from PCNA very quickly. Such behavior is important for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of lagging strand DNA synthesis in humans. They also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is not as high as previously thought.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but the process is inefficient. Here, we show that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA with high efficiency, and we demonstrate that the polymerase can also synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Thus, the polymerase can replicate genetic information and convert it into functional molecules, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life. This work provides a significant step toward the construction of a functional RNA-based cell.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a new method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are summarized. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic to eukaryotic cells. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a mechanism to control copper toxicity through the secretion of a family of isocyanide compounds derived from the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster. These compounds bind copper and impact cellular copper content, and have significant antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the role of natural products in fungal interactions with the human microbiome. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present day temperature of the Red Planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, such as plagioclase, cristobalite, and magnetite, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The amorphous silica is precipitated from multiple aqueous solutions, possibly derived from multiple infiltrations of variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly linked to the evolutionary history of the species, and that this history is in turn linked to the climate of the species’ native range. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here, we show that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by two mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the cause of the disease is unknown in most cases. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will enable the study of ALS in the laboratory and the development of new therapies.
