The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen colonization and disease. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the protein binds to the bacterial cell wall, perturbing the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and the gut barrier. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can use an arthropod antibacterial protein to influence the gut microbiota and enhance colonization. This work also provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiota in pathogen colonization and disease. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals, and the study of their evolution is a central topic in paleontology. The evolution of the avian tail, which is characterized by the presence of a short, fused pygostyle, is a major evolutionary event in the history of birds. However, the study of the evolution of the avian tail has been hindered by the lack of fossils of early branching birds. Here, we describe a new bird from the Early Cretaceous of China that represents the second earliest branching bird in the history of birds. This discovery increases our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail and the mosaic evolution of the avian tail and wings.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to predict how it will respond to changes in forcing. One of the reasons for this is that the climate system is coupled to the rest of the Earth system, and this coupling can lead to surprises. One such surprise is that the climate system may be more sensitive to radiative forcing than previously thought. We show here that this may be the case, and that the climate system may be more sensitive to radiative forcing than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to avoid detection by predators. In some species, the color of the animal is modified by the presence of pigments that absorb light in the same wavelength range as the animal’s own color. This phenomenon is called “color mimicry,” and it is thought to be a defense mechanism against predation. Here, we show that the color of some frogs and toads can be modified by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main component of the color of dead leaves. This is the first example of a serpin family protein that binds biliverdin, and it provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of color mimicry.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are thought to be responsible for the initiation and maintenance of breast cancer. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell marker. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression decreases NANOG mRNA methylation, increases NANOG protein levels, and increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which may contribute to the development of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well constrained by the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds, which define a precise age range for the extinction of 251.941 ± 0.037 to 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya. The carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle persisted for ∼500 ka. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This finding may help to explain the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under extreme conditions.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our findings highlight the importance of human activities in shaping fire regimes and the need to consider the role of fire in climate mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which animals regulate the activities of their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We show that chitin is provided to the squid only at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most mature. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thereby able to maintain a high population level in the organ. Finally, catabolism of chitin by the symbiont is also required for a periodic acidification of the organ, which enhances the level of oxygen available to the symbionts. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

The study of topics in text data is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method draws on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward the goal of understanding the latent structure of text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a valuable food resource for a variety of marine animals. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event that is associated with a virus. This study provides evidence that the virus is the cause of the disease and that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. The findings have implications for the management of this important ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The majority of AML patients have mutations in the transcription factor RUNX1, which is essential for the development of AML stem cells. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on AML stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML and that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, our findings suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, our study provides a rationale for the development of IL1RAP-targeting antibodies as a treatment option for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is home to a unique language, culture, and genetic diversity. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to study the genetic history of Madagascar in unprecedented detail. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia, with a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous across Madagascar, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. It also provides a framework for future studies of the human history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress genes involved in carbon utilization. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the expression of two additional genes. These results demonstrate that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to regulate gene expression.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the engineering of other protein molecules.

Crop expert surveys are a powerful source of information on crop status, but are rarely used in agricultural research. We show that these surveys can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. We also show that the crop expert surveys are not only useful for monitoring crop status, but can be used to detect anomalies in crop status, such as drought or pest outbreaks, and provide early warnings of potential yield losses. Finally, we show that the crop expert surveys are not only useful for monitoring crop status, but can be used to detect anomalies in crop status, such as drought or pest outbreaks, and provide early warnings of potential yield losses.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural mechanisms of language are still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, and information is stored in the changes in the excitability of neurons over time. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The release of carbon dioxide from soil is a major yet poorly understood flux in the global carbon cycle. This study provides a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life on Earth. It is also one of the most dramatic, as it is associated with the loss of photosynthesis and the emergence of a new lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is linked to a gradual relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the functional capacity of the plastid. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work emphasizes the need for urgent adaptation measures to reduce the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals by humans, in the laboratory, and in nature, in the form of anthropogenic quasicrystals, is a major advance in our understanding of the history of the Earth.

The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This study reveals that the fifth ring is formed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is a diiron protein, the other of which is an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein. These findings provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction in photosynthetic organisms. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common autoimmune disease of the CNS. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of a dual ASK1 inhibitor as a potential therapy for MS. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. This finding has important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation. (Show more)

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the effects of multiple risk genes and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has been difficult to determine because of its dual role in both Ca2+ entry and release. Here, we show that loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. We also identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy, and suggest new therapies for patients with this disorder. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. We show that these aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and that this non–cell-autonomous pathology can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent or reverse this process. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not fully understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The findings also provide a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential of MTX as a therapeutic target for viral infection. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a series of small-molecule dual SHMT inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo. A cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease that is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins. These proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS), are highly aggregation-prone and form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Thus, the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a common feature

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals are a promising platform for exploring the physics of many-body systems, including quantum simulation of topological phases of matter, quantum simulation of quantum chaos, and quantum simulation of quantum many-body systems. The photonic crystals can also be used to explore the physics of quantum optics, such as the generation of nonclassical states of light and the study of quantum metrology. The earliest angiosperms are poorly understood, and the origin of the group is still debated. Some have proposed that the group originated in a darkened forest habitat, while others have proposed that the group originated in an open aquatic habitat. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is a key topic in virology, but it is difficult to study because of the short time scales involved. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago, and we find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the substitution rate is an order of magnitude lower than previously thought. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been infecting humans for a long time. This is important for understanding the history of human evolution and the evolution of the human immune system. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These changes are being driven by the same natural processes that have always caused sea level to rise, but the rate of rise is now being affected by human activities. This study shows that the acceleration of sea level rise is consistent with the effects of climate change.

Pain is a major public health problem, with a large economic cost. The expectation is that pain will increase with age, as the body accumulates wear and tear and disease. However, in America today, pain is less than in other wealthy countries. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain has increased with age for midlife Americans, but less so for the elderly. Disaggregating the cross-section of ages by education, we find that the increase in pain with age is greater for those with less education, and that this increase is greater for each successive birth cohort. Thus, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of an enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, which is key to understanding why one substrate is able to react, while another is not. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that has a high case fatality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the only available treatment is supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is currently no licensed antiviral treatment for the novel coronavirus. The availability of remdesivir would also be of great importance in the event of a future pandemic.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which animals regulate the activities of their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We show that the glycan is provided only at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light, and that the glycan is catabolized in the luminescent crypts, where it increases the availability of oxygen to the symbiont. This glycan-mediated regulation of the symbiont population is likely to be a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is 10 times higher than it was in 1992. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this mindset can be sustained through a brief, online intervention. The findings suggest that the suspension rate can be reduced by changing the mindset of teachers, who are the most important influence on students’ behavior. This is a scalable, evidence-based intervention that can be implemented in schools.

The present study provides mechanistic insights into the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. The findings from this work provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from the present study also provide a molecular mechanism for the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The findings from this work provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from the present study also provide a molecular mechanism for the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells, but not other cell types. This requirement for sequential proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of global disease burden. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries are not sustainable, and there is a need to change this. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on sales. This is a simple and scalable intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we use quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes using a difference-in-differences design. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that this paper will help to inform the ongoing debate on the merits of vote-by-mail.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may mediate unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This process is blocked by an antagonist of CRFR1. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential target for the treatment of this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in a data set, given that we have chosen which associations to look for. The problem is important because it is becoming increasingly common to use data mining to find associations in large data sets. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The new methods are more powerful and more efficient than previous methods. They are also more transparent, in that they make explicit the assumptions that are being made about the data. This makes it easier to assess the validity of the inferences that are made from the data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces EC development from human adult skin fibroblasts. In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of “orphan” RTKs has led to the identification of their physiological ligands. In this study, we show that the augmentor ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leukocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning. We also show that the augmentor ligands of Alk and Ltk are essential for iridophore formation in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the function of the augmentor ligands and the mechanism of their activation of Ltk. These findings also have implications for the development of Alk inhibitors as cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of insulin resistance in T2D has been extensively studied, the molecular basis of β-cell dysfunction remains to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, is required for β-cell function. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells caused a decrease in β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, leading to impaired GSIS. Moreover, STING deficiency decreased Pax6 nuclear localization and expression in β-cells, which might be responsible for defective GSIS. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the role of STING in β-cell function and suggest that STING might be a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. Using silent trans-complementary mutants, we then demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The atheroprone environment, which is characterized by disturbed flow, is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential atherosclerotic lesion formation are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow promotes the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts. Our method is available as an open-source package, and the data and code used in this paper are available at https://github.com/j-m-s-s/neighborhood-improvement.jl. Our code is also available as a Docker image at https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in insects remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The study also provides a new target for the development of insect repellent. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn increases the metabolic energy demand of the coral host. This energy limitation, in turn, promotes the degradation of amino acids, thus forming a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients. In the absence of a tumor, the epithelium maintains a healthy microbiome composition. However, in the presence of a tumor, the microbiome can alter the activity of the epithelium, leading to barrier dysfunction and dysbiotic microbiota. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host–microbe homeostasis and tumorigenesis. It also opens the door to the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumorigenesis by targeting the microbiome. This work may also have implications for the development of intestinal tumors in humans. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. We find that breast cancer cells express the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1, which is up-regulated following treatment with chemotherapy. We show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab inhibits the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduces activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and reduces the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key question in the history of the last glacial period. We show that the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions that occurred exactly at the time of the last major volcanic episode in the Southern Hemisphere. The eruptions likely led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn likely caused a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, providing food, recreation, and commerce to hundreds of millions of people. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts, despite their importance to food security. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor, particularly in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security, biodiversity conservation, and ecosystem sustainability. This information can be used to prioritize management efforts and protect the benefits that rivers provide to the world’s poor.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery of a DLK-independent form of regeneration in C. elegans opens up a new avenue for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a property of a single pathway but rather a property of the entire nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, meiosis is a complex process that involves the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes, a process known as crossing over. The rate of crossing over is a key parameter that determines the efficiency of meiosis and the quality of the resulting gametes. Here, we describe the spatial pattern of crossing over in the model plant Mimulus, which is a key model organism for the study of meiosis. We find that the spatial pattern of crossing over is remarkably similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the spatial pattern of crossing over in plants may be a conserved feature of meiosis. This work provides a detailed map of the spatial pattern of crossing over in a flowering plant, which will be useful for the study of meiosis in other plants and in other organisms.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are dynamically active in a context-dependent manner. This hypothesis has been validated in a variety of neuroimaging modalities, but the RSN organization is not static but rather changes with age and in disease. Here, we show that metabolic imaging can provide a direct measure of the RSN organization in health and disease. We also show that metabolic imaging can provide a measure of the functional relevance of the RSN, which is lost in Parkinson’s disease. This work provides a new tool for the study of the organization of the human brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is essential for efficient translation and is the target of several classes of antiviral drugs. The existence of a 5′ cap in bacterial mRNA has been known for decades, but the existence of a 5′ cap in eukaryotic mRNA has been debated for over 20 y. Here we show that the 5′ cap is found in yeast mRNA, and that it is present on mRNA that encode proteins in both the nucleus and the mitochondria. This 5′ cap is not found on mRNA that are 5′ end-processed, suggesting that it is not a general feature of eukaryotic mRNA.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control reduced the risk of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the risk of macrovascular complications are unknown. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory of intensive glucose control. This study also shows that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences are maintained in monocytes, which are the main source of inflammatory cytokines in diabetes. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the metabolic memory of intensive glucose control and may explain why the risk of macrovascular complications is reduced for many years after the end of intensive glucose control. This may also explain why the risk of macrovascular complications is reduced for many years after the end of intensive glucose control.

The role of a cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for the study of fruit ripening, and the fruit of this species is consumed worldwide. The production of a distinctive aroma during ripening is a defining characteristic of the tomato fruit, and the chemistry of this aroma is poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of a wide range of nitrogenous aroma compounds in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a precursor to produce a series of aroma compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the chemistry of tomato fruit aroma, and the discovery of this pathway will be a major step forward in improving the flavor of this important crop. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is frequently investigated separately from other factors that may influence ecosystem performance. Here we show that changes in temperature can alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and that this relationship is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on the thermal tolerance of species, and suggest that biodiversity loss may be exacerbated by the additional impacts of environmental warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is a major focus of research. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying the complex neural activity patterns of this area in freely behaving animals. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from a large number of neurons in MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings suggest that grid cells may have a distinct functional organization from that of other cells in MEC. Our results also provide a framework for future studies of the functional organization of MEC. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with degeneration of nigral neurons and loss of their projections to the striatum, the classic target of dopamine. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of the nigrostriatal system that is preserved in Parkinson’s disease. This system, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is formed by striosomal neurons that project to striosomes, which in turn project to dopamine-containing nigral cell bodies. These cell bodies, in turn, project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. We suggest that striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are often told that we “click” with people, but how do we know when we do? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is regulated by the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by controlling the size of the Ca2+ store and the activity of the plasma membrane Ca2+ channel. These findings reveal a mechanism by which STIM1 contributes to the regulation of SAN automaticity. This study also provides insights into the role of STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ stores in other tissues. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonate (JA) levels and defense gene expression. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense system, and that Si priming of JA signaling may be a promising strategy for enhancing insect resistance in rice. This study also provides insights into the mechanism of Si-enhanced insect resistance in rice. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages by interferon-γ and lipopolysaccharide. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural mechanisms of language are still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, and information is stored in the changes in the excitability of neurons over time. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical area of research, as it is essential for the development of plant-based therapeutics and biofuels. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of plant-based therapeutics and biofuels. (Show more)

Nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs are often dominated by small tributaries, but these inputs have been largely ignored in the past. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the remaining 235 tributaries are responsible for 30% of the daily loads, and they are more important than the largest tributaries in terms of the nutrient loads that fuel algal blooms in nearshore areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in current efforts to reduce nutrient loading to lakes and reservoirs.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale thermodynamic equilibrium in the early universe is explained by the fact that rare combinations of initial conditions lead to a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the case of chemical networks.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, which is a hallmark of seizures. We then show that the changes in spectral composition are due to changes in the dynamics of cortical microcircuits. Finally, we show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to seizures even though the same changes in microcircuitry are tolerated in a model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms by which antibodies to the NMDA receptor cause seizures. They also suggest that the same mechanisms may underlie other forms of seizure-like activity in autoimmune encephalitis. This may lead to the development of new therapies for these conditions. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that the event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, which likely contributed to the demise of the last warm-water coral reef. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of abrupt climate change and the role of organic matter in triggering such events. This work also highlights the importance of studying abrupt climate change events that occurred during glacial periods, which are often overlooked in the literature.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its widespread use, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of conservation and climate mitigation efforts.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, of which only seven have been identified in humans. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. The sex of a vertebrate individual is determined by the genetic sex of the gonads, which in turn are determined by a cascade of developmental sex-determination genes. In species with a single sex-determination gene, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the gonads, resulting in two phenotypically distinct sexes. In species with multiple sex-determination alleles, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the gonads and the sex of the body, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four genotypic sexes, and that the sex of the body is determined by the sex of the gonads and the sex of the body, resulting in four modularly variable phenotypes. These results suggest that the evolution or loss of sex-determination alleles can result in the modular variation of secondary sexual characteristics. This modular variation may be important for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination in vertebrates. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble lipofuscin, a byproduct of oxidative metabolism. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, which are formed by photooxidation of vitamin A. We show that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the intracellular concentration of iron, which is known to be important for redox active energy and electron transfer. We also show that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the concentration of iron in the extracellular space. These findings have implications for the retina, which is a highly oxidative tissue, and for the retina, which is challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble lipofuscin and vitamin A aldehyde adducts. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in ecology and evolution. In this study, we show that the evolution of predatory specialization in the marine cnidarian clade siphonophores has strong associations with prey type. This finding is important because it shows that specialization is not a dead end, but rather a common evolutionary strategy that can be followed by different predators. Our results also show that the evolution of predatory specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of the organisms that feed on them. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest hominin fossils are more than 1.8 My old. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human behavior. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a series of small-molecule dual SHMT inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo. A cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We show that formate, the one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized, despite a growing body of literature that shows that having access to these landscapes can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. In this study, we show that deforestation over a 5-y period (2008–2013) led to a reduction in household fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation over the survey period led to an increase in consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study finds a causal link between deforestation and people’s dietary quality, and the results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.
